intro: Rhipidoglossum ovale, commonly known as the oval-leafed moss, is a species of liverwort belonging to the family Pottiaceae. It is a small, mat-forming plant that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rocky crevices. The plant features closely spaced, ovate-shaped leaves that are often covered in a layer of fine, translucent cells. Its reproductive structures, called capsules, are borne on short, upright stalks and release spores when mature. Rhipidoglossum ovale is an important component of many microhabitats, contributing to soil stability and providing habitat for small invertebrates.
